results.title: Legs
results.creator_credit: Franklin R. Levy, Ron Parker, Jerrold Freedman, Catalina productions, Comworld Productions and Radio City Music Hall Productions
results.brief_description: Three young hopefuls, Terry (Deborah Geffner), Melissa (Maureen Teefy) and Lisa (Shanna Reed) aspire to become part of the The Radio City Music Hall Rockettes, one of the world’s most famous and glamorous chorus lines. The story revolves around their auditioning, their hard work, successes and failures and of course their romances. Cast also includes John Heard, Sheree North, David Marshall Grant and Gwen Verdon.

results.title: Legends and the life of the Inuit
results.creator_credit: Richard Robesco, Gaston Sarault and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: In the vast windswept whiteness of the North, voices sing, chant and tell stories. Inuit children gather round to hear elders tell about the owl who is flattered into letting its prey escape, or why the raven is black, or the terrible fate of the selfish woman who abandons her blind son, or how the wily hunters manages to escape from the giants who want to eat him. Legends are more than a way of passing the long Arctic night. Often speaking through indigenous animals, they transmit the ancestral wisdom essential to survival in this inhospitable land: the need to know oneself, to share with others and to live in harmony with nature. In Legends and Life of the Inuit, these timeless tales are evoked through animation, prints, and carvings in bone, ivory or soapstone. Traditional life is depicted in archival photographs and footage from ethnographic documentaries. The jarring intrusion of scenes of modern life in the North hints at the danger of this ancient culture being lost as the Inuit embrace southern values. This video features excerpts from the Netsilik documentary series and films illustrating Inuit legends by animators Co Hoedeman (The Owl and the Lemming, The Owl and the Raven, Lumaaq and The Man and the Giant) and Caroline Leaf (The Owl Who Married a Goose).

results.title: Legend of the white snake = Bai she zhuan
results.creator_credit: Fu Chaowu and Shanghai Film Studio
results.brief_description: A love story about the tragic romance of an attractive lady, transformed from a thousand year old white snake, and a handsome young scholar. This legend takes place in the beautiful city of Hangzhou at West Lake. From a work by Tien Han and featuring Shanghai’s Second Peking Opera Troupe with the principal roles performed by Li Bingshu, Fang Xiaoya, Lu Boping, Su Shengyi, Chen Baiping. Chinese dialogue and subtitles.

results.title: Legend of the Wanganui River
results.brief_description: A Maori legend tells of the origin of the Wanganui River long ago. This film recounts the story, revealing something of the importance of the river to Maoris in the past, and illustrating its role today. The camera captures the mood of the river as it cascades down from its mountain source, swirls through narrow gorges, passes by dense forests ringing to the cry of birds, and eventually meets the sea near the city of Wanganui.

results.title: Legend of the overfiend = Urotsukidoji (D)
results.creator_credit: Hideki Takayama, Yasuhito Yamaki, Japan AV Network, Toshio Maeda and West Cape Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on the legend that the world as we know it is really made up of three worlds: the world of humans; the world of man-Beasts and the world of Monster Demons. Chojin is the superfiend whose destiny it is to unite the three worlds into the Land of Eternity every 3,000 years; a world filled with violence and chaos. Humanity must pit all its forces and wits to prevent this legend from becoming a reality. PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS ANIMATED FILM HAS AN ‘R’ RATING FOR PERSONS OVER THE AGE OF 18 DUE TO THE EXPLICIT VIOLENT AND SEXUAL NATURE OF ITS CONTENT.

results.title: Legend of birds
results.brief_description: Native birds of New Zealand and how they figure in Maori legends. How the Maoris caught birds and used their flesh and feathers. Studies of various birds including the owl, robin, tomtit, fantail, bell-bird, tui, wood pigeon, wecker, kiwi, takehai, grey warbler, kaka and kia.

results.title: Legend
results.creator_credit: Richard Raxlen, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A beauty-and-the-beast tale, enhanced and embellished by the filmmaker’s art. The screen becomes a luminous, shimmering dance of colors from which the story’s characters emerge like ephemeral beings from a mystic world, before melting away again into the chimerical void from which they came. The story is based on a west-coast Indian legend. The feats that the youth must perform to win his fair maiden are distinctly Indian ones, and masks are used in the telling of the story. Cast includes Stanley Coles, Patrick Cullen, Molly Dressel, Lubba Goy, Michael Hogan, Susan King, Mary Lou de la Salle, Jack Messinger, Sandy Nicholls, Marshall Webster. Photographed by David de Volpi. Edited by Margaret Wescott. Music by Bruce Mackay. Sound by Claude Delorme, Michel Hazel, Les Halman. (Awards: Toronto; New York)

results.brief_description: An experimental abstract film in which Henning Bendsten attempts a relation between abstract animation in the visuals and music on the sound track of the film.

results.title: Legacy: Olympic National Park
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Interior and United States. National Park Service
results.brief_description: Situated in the extreme north-west of Washington State, the Olympic National Park provides a variety of sea and animal life in an untamed, unspoiled wilderness. This film surveys the park from its dense forests and high country to its sea border and cold coastal waters.
results.creator_credit_for_label: United States. Dept. of the Interior and United States. National Park Service

results.title: Left out
results.creator_credit: Jim Purdy, John Kramer, John Spotton and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A film on unemployment and how it affects a family, as seen primarily through the eyes of a twelve-year-old. When Amy learns that she cannot go on a school field trip to Quebec City, she is devastated. Eventually, however, Amy grows to realize that a lack of money does not mean a lack of love, and that her parents try to compensate in other ways. Other elements in the film include the strain a man’s unemployment can place on husband and wife, and the tension it can create between parents and children. Part of a series of short dramatic films for children.
